source: Democratic Voice of Burma; Irrawaddy; Karen Information Center News; Khit Thit Media; Ministry of Defense - NUG; Mizzima; Myanmar Now; Shwe Phee Myay News Agency
notes: On 8 May 2025, in Nyaung Chay Htauk village (Shwegyin township, Bago district, Bago-East region), a combined force of ombined forces of the Karen National Liberation Army (KNU/KNLA), the People's Defense Force (PDF under NUG), Special Operation Force (SOF), White Dragon Battalion (South Division), Taung Nyo Column, Daw Na Column, Southern Eagle PDF, Special Operation Group (SOG), Dawn Company, Cloud Wings, People's Defense Force - Bago Region (PaKaPha), People Defense Force - Yangon Region, Mon State People's Defense Force, Kyaikhto Revolution Force (KRF), and United Democratic Force (Drone and Rocket forces) attacked the Myanmar military's LIB-598 base in the morning. The two sides then exchanged fire, and the military launched airstrikes several times using seven aircraft starting from around 6 am. The military from Thu Ye Thu Mein village also fired artillery rounds to assist the ground troops. The combined force subsequently captured the base at around 5 pm. The Ministry of Defense - NUG, Shwe Phee Myay News Agency, Narinjara News, Karen Information Center News, Khit Thit Media, and Mizzima reported that they recovered 30 bodies of military soldiers, captured 6 military soldiers and 7 family members. The joint forces also seized a total of 83 different weapons - including point-5 machine guns, 75mm recoilless rifles, 81mm and 60mm mortars - along with three jammers and various types of ammunition. According to Myanmar Now, 8 members of the combined force were killed, and around 30 others sustained injuries. Fatalities coded as 38 using the most recent estimate.

actor1: KIO/KIA: Kachin Independence Organization/Kachin Independence Army
assoc_actor_1: KPDF: Kachin Region People's Defense Force
notes: On 8 May 2025, in Hseng Hpa Yar village (Hpakant township, Mohnyin district, Kachin state), joint forces of the Kachin Independence Army (KIO/KIA) and Kachin Region People's Defense Force (KPDF) attacked two Myanmar military columns advancing towards Hpakant town. The military troops were subsequently forced to retreat to Kat Hmaw village. Several military troops were killed. There were an unspecified number of fatalities. Unspecified fatalities coded as 3.

The Myanmar military conducted drone strikes and fired heavy weapons during the armed clash. Casualties unknown.

On 8 May 2025, in Si Son Kone village (Lemyethna township, Hinthada district, Ayeyarwady region), the Myanmar military troops stationed in the village fired heavy weapons indiscriminately toward nearby areas. Casualties unknown.

notes: On 8 May 2025, in Mogoke town (Mogoke township, Pyinoolwin district, Mandalay region), the Ta'ang National Liberation Army beat and detained a man for allegedly shouting at the members of the Ta'ang National Liberation Army regarding an affair related to his estate at around 4:00 pm.

On 8 May 2025, in Win Kan village (Shwegyin township, Bago district, Bago-East region), the Myanmar military forces conducted airstrikes by dropping 500-pound bombs on the village using Y-12 fighter jets from 8:05 am to 4 pm. Casualties unknown.

On 8 May 2025, in Ma Kyee Kone village (Maungdaw township, Maungdaw district, Rakhine state), an unexploded ordnance detonated as children picked it up and played with it. The explosion instantly killed one child, and another boy subsequently died on the way to the hospital. A 75-year-old elderly civilian was also injured in the blast. No group has claimed responsibility for the unexploded ordnance.

On 8 May 2025, in Thabaung township (Pathein district, Ayeyarwady region), the Myanmar military arrested 4 civilians at 7 miles on Kyat Thon Kwin-Thea Phyu road for allegedly supporting the People's Defense Force.

Movement of forces: Around 7 May 2025 (as reported), in Htee Khee village (Dawei township, Dawei district, Tanintharyi region), more than 50 Myanmar military soldiers from IB-25 and police deserted the Htee Khee military outpost, crossed the border and fled to Thailand.

On 7 May 2025, in Gangaw township (Gangaw district, Magway region), the Myanmar military launched airstrikes on three unidentified locations in northern Gangaw township using two fighter jets at around 8:30 pm. There were no casualties.

Displacement: On 7 May 2025, in Hlaingbwe township (Hpa-An district, Kayin state), around 1,000 locals from Mae La, Kar Te, Htee Ka Haw and Thayt Maw Ku villages were forced to flee after the KNLA troops attacked the Myanmar military outpost (coded separately).

source: Democratic Voice of Burma; Irrawaddy; Khit Thit Media; Mizzima; Myanmar Now
notes: Displacement: On 7 May 2025, in Paingkyon town (Hlaingbwe township, Hpa-An district, Kayin state), following drone strikes carried out by a combined force of the Karen National Liberation Army (KNU/KNLA) and allied forces against Myanmar military camp (coded separately), 327 civilians were forced to flee to Thailand. They were sheltered in two temporary sites by Thai authorities.

Movement of forces: Around 7 May 2025 (as reported), in Hpa-An township (Hpa-An district, Kayin State), the Myanmar military established navy bases in three locations, including the Hpar Me Taung area and near Ta Yoke Hla and Hpar Kat villages, along the Salween River. More navy ships and speedboats were also deployed at each base. Locals speculated that the military is preparing defensive bases as it fears the clashes in Kawkareik might spread to Hpa-An.

On 7 May 2025, in Hsipaw township (Kyaukme district, Shan-North state), a mine exploded and injured a 32-year-old man when he stepped on the mine planted by an unknown armed group while he was collecting wood near the military IB-23 around 12:30 pm. His leg was injured and sent to the Hsipaw hospital.

assoc_actor_1: Government of Myanmar (2021-) State Administration Council
notes: On 6 May 2025, in Yangon - Hlaing (Yangon-West district, Yangon region), the Myanmar military and the No.1 ward local administrator abducted a young man on Zayyar Thake Di 2 street in the No.1 ward for forced military conscription who fled from high-rise buildings after an earthquake.

On 6 May 2025, in Hlaingtharyar township (coded as Yangon - Hlaingtharya-East) (Yangon-North district, Yangon region), garment factory workers held a protest at their workplace against the Myanmar Stage garment factory in the Tha Ma Kone Apyin Pa Dan area demanding recalculation of their wages after salary cuts were implemented in April. The workers' demands include reinstatement of skill allowances to their previous levels, no deduction of attendance bonuses for legal leaves, setting reasonable production quotas that workers can achieve, no deduction of daily wages for social security leaves, and refund of previously deducted daily wages, provision of casual leave according to the law, hiring new workers when production lines are understaffed, providing social security cards to workers as soon as possible and signing employment contracts (EC) after three months of service.

notes: On 26 April 2025, near Maung Mei Shaung village (Dawei township, Dawei district, Tanintharyi region), a combined force of resistance forces attacked the Har Lee Kwayt camp stationed by about 30 Myanmar military troops at around 5 am. The two sides then exchanged fire until the evening, and the combined force subsequently captured the camp at around 5 pm. During the clash, the military launched airstrikes, and the No.302 artillery unit fired artillery rounds to assist the ground troops. The combined force subsequently set fire to the camp. The combined force includes the Du Ya Ka Column, the Karen National Liberation Army (battalion 12 - company 5), the Tavoy People Liberation Force, the Dawei National Liberation Army, the People's Defense Force - Yebyu (PaKaPha), the Oak Awe Column (Dawei), the Dawei Guerrilla Revolution Force, the Sky Ghost Drone Force, the Federal Polaris Force, and the Dawei East Forest People's Defense Force. Khit Thit Media reported that at least 10 military troops were killed, while the Independent Mon News Agency reported that about 20 military troops were killed. 16 others also surrendered to the defense forces. According to Khit Thit Media and Mizzima, a military captain also committed suicide by shooting himself, while the Independent Mon News Agency reported that his soldiers helped the military captain end his life before their surrender, as no military reinforcements arrived to save them. The combined force also seized nine MA-1 rifles, one MA-2 rifle, six MA-3 rifles, one MA-4 rifle, one MA-11 rifle, and one BA-100 rifle. Fatalities coded as 10, using the lowest estimate.

source: Khit Thit Media; Mizzima; Network Media Group

The villagers who were detained from Kha Yin Chaung village were released on 5 April in the afternoon.
On 31 March 2025, in Zar Di village (Yebyu township, Dawei district, Tanintharyi region), the Myanmar military raided the village and detained 5 villagers. They were released later on 3 April.

notes: Other: On 29 March 2025, the National Unity Government (NUG) announced that offensive operations of the People's Defense Forces would be temporarily suspended for two weeks from 30 March to allow emergency rescue operations for people trapped in homes and buildings that collapsed due to earthquake damage. On 12 April 2025, the Ministry of Defense (MOG) under the National Unity Government (NUG) announced an offensive operation to remain suspended from 13-20 April to carry out earthquake relief operations effectively. They instructed the People's Defense Force and affiliated local defence groups to provide necessary assistance and protection to domestic and international humanitarian aid organisations. Location coded as Nay Pyi Taw.

Security measures: On 28 March 2025, the Myanmar military forces declared a state of emergency in accordance with the Natural Disaster Management Law following a powerful 7.7-magnitude earthquake that struck Mandalay, causing significant damage and widespread disruption. Location coded as Nay Pyi Taw.

assoc_actor_1: Moe Tar Taik Nei Pyi Thu Kar Kwei Yay Tatphwe: Moe Tar Area People's Defense Force; People's Defense Force - Katha District
source: Democratic Voice of Burma; Irrawaddy; Kachin News Group; Khit Thit Media; Mizzima; Myanmar Now; Narinjara News; Radio Free Asia
notes: On 16 March 2025, near Nat Yae Twin and Pin Ma Lut villages (coded as Pin Ma Lut) (Katha township, Katha district, Sagaing region), a combined force of the Kachin Independence Army (KIO/KIA), the People's Defense Force - Katha District (battalion 1), and the Moe Tar Area People's Defense Force (PaKaPha) continued to attack a Myanmar military column of about 150 troops under the LID-77 for the second day as they were traveling from Katha to Nat Yae Twin village. The DVB and the Kachin News Group reported that the combined force collected four bodies of the military troops during a two-day battle. Meanwhile, the initial reports of Khit Thit Media and Mizzima reported 40 military troops were killed during the two-day battle, while Irrawaddy reported that the combined force discovered at least 10 bodies of the military troops. The latest reports of Myanmar Pressphoto Agency, Khit Thit Media, Mizzima, and Narinjara News reported that 33 military troops were killed. The combined force also captured 29 military troops, including a captain, as prisoners of war during the two-day battle. They also seized several weapons and ammunition. 2 members of the combined force were also killed. Fatalities coded as 35 (33 military troops and 2 members of the combined force), using the most recent estimate. 35 fatalities split across two days (15 - 16 March), and coded as 18 for this event.

Both sides exchanged fire for about 6 hours. During the armed clash, the military conducted airstrikes and dropped around six bombs around 10 am and the navy ships fired heavy weapons. Locals were forced to flee as the military conducted airstrikes and fired heavy weapons. The combined force also seized an M-3 gun, 9 cartridges, three grenades and some bullets from the military. Karen Information Center News and Mizzima reported that 12 military soldiers and 2 members of the Du Ya Ka Column were killed.

notes: On 1 February 2025, in Me Pa Li village (Bilin township, Thaton district, Mon state), a combined force of the Karen National Liberation Army (KNU/KNLA), the People's Defense Force (under the NUG), the Bamar People's Liberation Army, and the Force for Federal Democracy attacked the Myanmar military's Me Pa Li camp at around 8 am and subsequently captured it at around 1:30 pm. The military launched airstrikes with Jetfighters 33 times and with Y-12 aircraft one time. The military (LIB-405) and (LIB-3) fired artillery rounds to assist the ground troops during the clash. The combined force captured 29 military troops, including a battalion commander and a tactical commander, as prisoners of war. They also seized several weapons and ammunition, including one 122mm artillery weapon and two 120mm artillery weapons. According to Khit Thit Media and Independent Mon News Agency, the PDF claimed that about 40 military troops were killed. Meanwhile, based on the official report of the KNU/KNLA, the Karen Information Center News and Radio Free Asia reported that 29 military troops were killed. 3 members of the combined force were also killed, and about 33 injured. Fatalities coded as 32 (29 military troops and 3 members of the combined force), using the lowest estimates.
